August 5, 2012: Fiction
THE FALLEN ANGEL, by Daniel Silva. (Harper/HarperCollins, $27.99.) Gabriel
Allon, an art restorer and occasional spy for the Israeli secret service, discovers a
global criminal enterprise behind a murder in Rome.
GONE GIRL, by Gillian Flynn. (Crown, $25.) A woman disappears on the day of her
fifth anniversary; is her husband a killer?
I, MICHAEL BENNETT, by James Patterson and Michael Ledwidge. (Little, Brown,
$27.99.) A New York detective takes refuge with his 10 children in an upstate cabin.
SHADOW OF NIGHT, by Deborah Harkness. (Viking, $28.95.) An Oxford
scholar/witch and a vampire geneticist pursue history, secrets and each other in
Elizabethan London.
CREOLE BELLE, by James Lee Burke. (Simon & Schuster, $27.99.) The Louisiana
detective Dave Robicheaux hunts for a missing Cajun singer.
BACKFIRE, by Catherine Coulter. (Putnam, $26.95.) The F.B.I. agents Dillon Savich
and Lacey Sherlock investigate the murder of a judge.
THE SANDCASTLE GIRLS, by Chris Bohjalian. (Doubleday, $25.95.) A woman of
Armenian descent pursues her family’s history and explores a World War I romance
— and a secret.
A DANCE WITH DRAGONS, by George R. R. Martin. (Bantam, $35.) Book 5 of "A
Song of Ice and Fire."
THE NEXT BEST THING, by Jennifer Weiner. (Atria, $26.99.) A young woman who
moves to Hollywood to make it in television finds success, but her life remains
complicated.
CLOSE YOUR EYES, by Iris Johansen and Roy Johansen. (St. Martin's, $27.99.)
Kendra Michaels, who developed investigative skills when she was blind for the first
20 years of her life, tracks a serial killer who murdered her ex-lover.
WICKED BUSINESS, by Janet Evanovich. (Bantam, $28.) The Salem, Mass., pastry
chef Lizzy Tucker and her partner, Diesel, take up a quest for a powerful ancient
relic.
BEAUTIFUL RUINS, by Jess Walter. (Harper/HarperCollins, $25.99.) Ruins both
emotional and architectural, in Italy, Hollywood and elsewhere, figure in this
sweeping novel.
CALICO JOE, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $24.95.) A pitcher beans a promising
rookie, ending both their careers; years later, the pitcher’s son brings them together.
EARTH UNAWARE, by Orson Scott Card and Aaron Johnston. (Tor/Tom Doherty,
August 5, 2012
Non-Fiction
WILD, by Cheryl Strayed. (Knopf, $25.95.) A woman's account of a life-changing
1,100-mile hike along the Pacific Crest Trail.
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House, $27.) An Olympic runner's
story of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
THE AMATEUR, by Edward Klein. (Regnery, $27.95.) A journalist argues that
President Obama is callow and unable to lead.
KILLING LINCOLN, by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard. (Holt, $28.) The host of
"The O'Reilly Factor" recounts the events surrounding the assassination of
Abraham Lincoln.
THE DREAM TEAM, by Jack McCallum. (Ballantine, $28.) The 1992 U.S. men’s
Olympic basketball team.
STEVE JOBS, by Walter Isaacson. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) A biography of the
entrepreneur and Apple visionary, who died in October 2011.
THE MOBILE WAVE, by Michael Saylor. (Vanguard, $25.99.) A high-tech
entrepreneur discusses the transformative potential of mobile computing.
A YEAR UP, by Gerald Chertavian. (Viking, $26.95.) A former Wall Street banker
describes the program he founded that trains young urban adults for jobs.
THE COMMUNIST, by Paul Kengor. (Threshold/Mercury Ink, $27.) A professor at
Grove City College argues that Frank Marshall Davis, an elderly black Communist
whom Barack Obama met as a teenager in Honolulu, was his secret mentor.
YES, CHEF, by Marcus Samuelsson. (Random House, $27.) The award-winning
chef discusses his career and recalls growing up as an Ethiopian child adopted by
a Swedish family.
THE PRESIDENTS CLUB, by Nancy Gibbs and Michael Duffy. (Simon &
Schuster, $32.5.) Two journalists examine the relationships between presidents
and their predecessors.
COWARDS, by Glenn Beck and Kevin Balfe. (Threshold Editions/Mercury Radio
Arts, $28.) The radio host and founder of GBTV discusses 13 lies that politicians,
academics and the media perpetuate.
OUT OF THE BLUE, by Victor Cruz with Peter Schrager. (Celebra, $26.95.) The
New York Giants wide receiver reflects on his life and career.
IMAGINE, by Jonah Lehrer. (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $26.) An account of the
science of creativity argues that it is not a gift but a thought process that can be
learned.
